Interview Descriptions: Met one-on-one with future adviser and other faculty involved in the grant I would work on.  Was reimbursed for visit to the campus (flights, hotel, and meals).  Very good interview experience.  Was given introduction to the Department with another four perspective students.  I don't think many Departments do group interviews of potential students any more.  It is very one-on-one with your future (potential) adviser.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in this position?

title: Research Technologist III Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Penn State (Hershey, PA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: One face to face meeting with Direct Supervisor. Offered the job soon after but had a longer wait for official offer from institution. This seems to be the case with most jobs here, there is an immediate verbal offer but the written official offer takes longer.
Interview Questions: Asked specifics about certain past research

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in Jan 2011
Interview Descriptions: The interview process depends on which professor and which research group you want to work with. Depending on that, you may be called for a face-to-face interview with the principal investigator of that team.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in research?

title: Teaching Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Dec 2010
Interview Descriptions:
The hiring and interview process was extremely simple. My professor suggested that I become a TA at the end of the semester and gave me a recommendation. It's been a few years, so I can't remember the specifics. I think I just filled out a really simple application and was basically guaranteed the position. I think they also did a background check. I then had to fill out some paperwork for payroll and was set. You have to "re-apply" each semester (you really just let them know you're coming back so they know whether or not to keep you in the system). 

After being a TA for 1.5 years, I was recommended for the teaching intern (TI) program. This program is fantastic. If you and the professor get everything figured out right, you can get a great experience and feel for what it is actually like to be a professor. You have a lot more responsibility and do a lot more work, but it is worth it.
Interview Questions: There weren't really any questions, you just had to have demonstrated knowledge and the ability to help others throughout the year.

title: Admissions Officer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Penn State (Harrisburg, PA) in Nov 2010
Interview Descriptions: Interview and hiring process went well.  HR made several mistakes though.  Culture is open to change and positive.
Interview Questions: Where do you see yourself in 10 years?

title: Tech Support Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Oct 2010
Interview Descriptions: well prepare to the job interview by looking at JD and asking around
Interview Questions: what skills you have to handle those tasks

title: Administrative Support Assistant II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions:
Apply for jobs at PSU entail filling out the online application and then applying directly for jobs on the Human Resources job posting site. I applied to over 70 positions before securing this position, which is at least three steps down from my former job. The job market is small and those seeking employment is enormous. As one of the few primary employers in central PA, I knew I would be in for some competition.

I was contacted via telephone for an 1st interview. I met with a panel of 5 interviewers. All went well and I was called back in a few weeks for a 2nd interview. This interview was a panel of 7 interviewers. The questions were standard interview type questions like tell me about a time you exceeded expectations/ tell me about a time you made a mistake at work and how you handled it. Then a few more questions to get to know me better were included that were specific to my work history.

Another few weeks and they requested to meet me one more time. This meeting was a job offer.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you disagreed with your boss.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at Penn State in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: I was admitted to Penn State Department of Electrical Engineering with a temporary advisor. I came in and went through the new grad student orientation and started to send emails and talk to professors. Some are not interested in having admitted-without-an-advisor student some are. Talked to my now advisor and stayed in his lab working and learning from older student. After a few month, he took me as his student and started to pay me before my first summer.
Interview Questions: What do you want to do? What is your interest?

title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in May 2010
Interview Descriptions: Conventional 1:1 interview. You get asked about your research and how your background will fit with the goals of the mentor. Personality questions such as responsibility and how you would handle the high level of pressure to publish. Organizational skills, etc.
Interview Questions: If you caught one of your labmates cheating on their results, what would you do?

title: Systems Administrator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: Submit resume and cover letter through online application site, wait 8 weeks (common at Penn State). I got a phone interview with the hiring manager and a colleague. The phone interview included some Unix admin questions and a "homework" assignment: within the next hour, e-mail me a little script that will parse a certain kind of text file and make certain changes. I did so. Later I was called for an in-person interview and spoke with the hiring manager and his director. After this there was a long time, about 4 weeks, before an offer was made even though I was told that they were eager to hire.
Interview Questions: Aforementioned "homework" given at the end of the phone interview was unexpected. Otherwise the interview questions were the common getting-to-know-you type and some technical questions to verify I knew about the technologies I listed in my resume and cover letter.

title: Cafeteria Worker Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Penn State (Reading, PA) in Apr 2010
Interview Descriptions: Came in, asked some few basic questions such as "Why do you wish to work here?", got hired on the spot.
Interview Questions: Why would you like to work here?

title: Associate Director, Academic Learning Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in Jan 2010
Interview Descriptions: Be prepared.  The overall process can be intimidating depending on the position you are trying to reach.  It is not that bad once you get going.  Some people only do the interview via skype at this point.  However, if you have to do a presentation be aware that the room will be crowded and there will be people from many different areas of outreach.  In fact, you may never see those people again in the time you work there.  As long as you do your research beforehand, you should be fine.
Interview Questions: You're young, so how would you handle supervising those of us that have more experience?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Jan 2010
Interview Descriptions: Talk to desired professor, luckily the professor likes me, so I got the position.
Interview Questions: Not really had difficult question

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in Dec 2009
Interview Descriptions: The process started with a referral by another teaching assistant.  I was a student in his class.  Then there was a phone interview with the professor and he reviewed my work in his class.  Following that there was a 1-on-1 interview with the professor and some of the teaching coordinators.
Interview Questions: Biggest challenges?

title: Postdoctoral Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in Oct 2009
Interview Descriptions: Most of the interviewing was conducted with one-on-one discussions with the advising professor, who was incredibly accommodating and friendly. This can vary from professor to professor, but my experience was certainly positive.  I had to do additional interviews with the company that was sponsoring the project. Again, this was a positive experience, but did add to the length of the interview process.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: R&D Engineer Level I Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Aug 2009
Interview Descriptions:
It was a series of interviews with people from different parts of the division. Some I would be working with and others I would not be. Hierarchy-wise, it was made up of people recently hired up to the division head. It was a total of about 7 interviews over the course of a few hours. Also had a tour of the facility and such. The people were very nice, the office kind of drab (no windows out due to security).

Best advice: Just be yourself and let them know what you want. If it sounds a little ... too good to be true or confusing have them clarify, as you might be signing up to be a professional paper pusher.
Interview Questions: I don't really remember but I did not have to do anything technical. Typical what do you want and where do you want to be in X years type questions.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: I first connected with faculty in the department in which I wanted a position.  What was available at the time was an advertised position that I qualified for and the faculty member put me in touch with the person needing a research associate.  I sent my CV and we emailed back and forth informally as the employer checked on my references (mutual acquaintances).  I was invited out to interview in-person for two days.  They hosted the visit and did an excellent job of hosting by making me feel welcome, taking care of all travel and expenses, made sure I was taken out to meals with other faculty, staff, and students, and included me in standing meetings all to get a feel of the environment.  About a week later, I was offered the position and if I tentatively agreed to the arrangements then they would start the paperwork.  I believe the interview process was less about my abilities (since my CV, references, and job talk spoke to that) but was more about gauging my work style and how well I fit in with the culture there.
Interview Questions: The most unexpected question was "what do you think?" regarding the position without any clear description of the expectations or responsibilities.  There was no difficult question related to skill or competence that was asked of me.

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Penn State in Mar 2009
Interview Descriptions: I was enrolled by phone interview. It's a nice and easy process. I did not have a hard time in my interview.
Interview Questions: Some time you have no access to the equipment you want use. And as the academic environment, it's not highly competitive.

title: Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in Jul 2008
Interview Descriptions: The interviewing process was very short. I spoke with 4 people but there really wasn't a position.
Interview Questions: Didn't know if they had a job so they couldn't ask many questions

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at Penn State (State College, PA) in May 2008
Interview Descriptions: I found the lab which I was interested in primarily through the web. I contacted their administrative assistant who set me up with an with a visit to the lab. The visit started with me giving the lab a 30 minute presentation covering my research followed by about 30 minutes of questions. We took a lunch break and then I spoke with individuals one on one.
Interview Questions: Can you describe your past research and how it relates to the directions of the lab?

title: PhD Candidate Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in Mar 2008
Interview Descriptions: You are supposed to present a research proposal that you have to present and defend before a research committee. It is very research-focused, although fundamental knowledge is supposed to be evaluated also. The round of questions lasts about 30 - 45 min with each of the 3 reviewers/interviewers, after which they deliberate and reach a decision about your acceptance in the doctoral program.
Interview Questions: Depict a visual image of the physical and chemical processes that happen in the combustion chamber as the fuel and air enter into it, and compare it to the process when oxygen enriched air enters.

title: Market Research & Strategy Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Penn State (University Park, PA) in Jun 2007
Interview Descriptions:
From what I've learned from other employees, I was hired rather quickly.  It typically takes Penn State months to act on applications, so don't get discouraged if you don't hear from them right away.

Everything is done through their website.  If you know someone who can recommend you, then they're much more inclined to call you.  Otherwise, they typically only hire other Penn State employees.

Your best bet, if you want a good job at Penn State, is to take a job that you're overqualified for.  You'll just have to endure the menial work for months or years, and hope that a job opens up in an area that you'd like to work in.  This holds true for both laborers and professionals.
Interview Questions:
Questions were generic.  Mostly, the interview process is a chance for them to go over your resume and qualifications with you.  They use a panel so that multiple people can all report on their instincts about you.

Make sure that you don't offend anybody on the panel.  Because of the way the interview process is set up, even one person can torpedo your job interview.

Be prepared to demonstrate that you are willing to take initiative in your job!  This is very important for the marketing group.
